climbs.name: Consolation Prize
climbs.fa: Shaun Neufeld, Max de Jong, Sigourney de Jong summer 2022

content.description:
A slightly overhanging, splitter hand and finger crack. Tops out on the lower west ridge,



North face of the west ridge. Approach as for the west ridge but traverse out onto the shelf as if approaching the north face and work your way up to the base aiming for the obvious crack.

At least doubles of the hand and finger sizes.

climbs.name: The Needle and the Damage Done (NE Face of SE Buttress)

content.description:
An attempt to climb the SE Buttress that ended up climbing entirely new rock on the face between the SE and NE ridges. The first pitch takes 5.8 slabs, and had icefall hazard in May 2005; the second a wide flake and face above. The next pitch went more easily up a slab and ledge to a steep corner that necessitated excavating holds out of turf. Another short pitch ended at a ledge with a blank wall above. A traverse 30 feet right across the ledge led to a mud-filled crack. Five moves of aid up the mud crack, excavating TCU placements with a nut tool with water running out of the crack and then yarding on them, led to better 5.9 climbing. Another short pitch or two of slabs and cracks led to the summit.

Probably better when drier, later in the season. May 2005 was unseasonably dry and low-snowpack. Normally this face holds snow until July.



Start about 100 feet right of the toe of the SE buttress. See TOPO

Full rack with doubles to triples of finger sized pieces and gear up to 4.5"

This face is mostly known for being unimpressive looking. A steep band at the bottom gives way to a large shield of low-angle heather or snow. Near the top, there's another steep band. It has been climbed both summer (solo) and winter. In summer it's heathery and not very good climbing. In winter, there are two distinct M4ish cruxes and also a lot of steep snow and frozen heather that's not very difficult. Sort of two boulder problem pitches separated by steep hiking. It's been done several times but no one ever recommends it.



From the west ridge trail, traverse out onto the shelf below the north face of the west ridge, and where it ends, climb the first pitches up onto the shield of slabs. Diagonal across those aiming to join in with the top of the NE ridge.

some gear is useful in winter especially the type of stuff you can pound into frozen heather or hammer into an ice and snow filled crack and not have rip out. Spectres, hexes, tri cams, stuff like that will be the only gear you get in.

climbs.name: Northeast ridge via Markhor Peak
climbs.fa: Non-integral ascent avoiding the cruxes by Karl Ricker and party in summer 1985; Integral ascent by Max de Jong and party in early winter 1985

content.description:
One of the best scrambles in SW BC. From the highway, head up the east side of the creek draining the north face of Needle, and gain open slabs. Follow these (easy scrambling and hiking) to the subsummit of Markhor Peak. Now the fun begins.

Descend staying as close as possible to the ridge crest along the SW ridge of Markhor. The descent will get more and more difficult without you ever feeling quite that you need to break out the rope,. Eventually you'll find yourself at the Leg-Eating Crack, an offwidth crack in a dihedral. It's the perfect width and angle for hiking boots as you downclimb but you may need to stack your hands with a fist if you face in. Descend more easily from there to the Markhor-Needle col. 

Now proceed over two bumps along the ridge between Needle and Markhor staying on the south side of the ridge crest or exactly on it. The highlight is a beautiful arete that you downclimb with exhilirating exposure. 

The final climb out of the last notch involves a left-leaning diagonal flake/corner of poor quality rock thatr is short but exposed. People sometimes rope up for this but it isn't any harder than what you've already done. From here, amble up low-angle corners to the summit of Needle. Descend via the west ridge.



Park as for the west ridge but take to the bush on the east side of the highway works yard and follow the ridge on the other side of thre creek from the Needle hiking trail

a helmet and good boots

A diagonal ramp that trends up the south face to end on the huge ledge just southeast of the summit. A great route to do if you have already done the west ridge multiple times, Beware of goats and of hikers above trundling stuff on you.



Most easily reached from the toe of the west ridge. Descend south for a ways until you can contour underneath the steep rock forming the south face of the west ridge. You will know you're at the base of the ramp when you see it in front of you.

n/a; maybe a helmet

climbs.name: Southeast buttress
climbs.fa: Paul Starr and partner, June 1974 (Fairley guide lists Starr and Douglas but Douglas says he wasn't part of FA party)

content.description:
A problematic route that may only have ever had one or two ascents. Start up the crest of the southeast buttress and climb a succession of bushy and rotten cracks until you hit a blank diamond shaped wall about three pitches up. At this point it's not clear exactly what the hell the FA party did to get by but they likely traversed around it on the south, maybe with a tension traverse. One established past this perplexing crux it's about 5.7 to the top.



The start can be reached by either climbing over Markhor, and down into the east face bowl, or, go to the base of the west ridge and then traverse under the south slopes of the peak. Either way takes about 3-4 hours to the base with a full rack.

Full rack to 4". Crack gloves help.

climbs.name: West Ridge
climbs.fa: likely by First Nations ~10,000 to ~8000 years ago

content.description:
A fun scramble. Class 2 (MP doesn't have a rating for Class 2 so it's listed as 3rd class).

 Scamper easily up to the first crux which involves deking around a flake and then up a diagonal crack. Continue hiking a level section of the ridge to the upper crux, which involves moving right across a slab, up the slab, turn the corner and a short stemming problem up a dihedral on enormous holds. Continue more easily to the summit. Delightful solid rock throughout. Descend the same way. 4 hours or so round trip from the cars.



Hike the Parks trail from the highway parking lot to the Needle-Flatiron col. Now you are at the base of the west ridge. 


in recent years the cruxes have sported unnecessary fixed ropes at times. please remove such garbage if you find it on route.
South across the highway from Yak
